Hopkins Reliance on Government Grows
By JACK HOLLIS
According to Dr. Bruce J. Partridge, Vice-President
for Administration, 53% of the funds for the school's
Operating budget in the vear oA-7.
107g_irsice-1-915995.9.)111 governmental sources, an increase ot
Although this situation is what was termed by Dr.
Partridge as a "heavy reliance" on federal funds, Hopkins
..1.. dependence on government money has almost
always been to its own advantage. In fact, the University
is in a better position than many other institutions.
Hazards
In the period 1967-68 the total amount of money
received from the government was $35,414,549, almost
all of it going for research of one form or another. The
figure was approximately $9 million in 1959, when the
total operating budget was about $21 million, an amount
that has since risen to its present level of almost $69
rnillion. The statistics do not include the Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) in Silver Spring, which has a
Navy contract of $52,765,000 which Hopkins just
administrates.

There are two potential hazards within this large
dependence on government grants and contracts. Ross
Jones, Vice-President for University Affairs, stated that
"the ultimate danger is that government through control
of money will dictate what to do, but this has not happened in the last 20-25 years.
"What We Want"
The possibility of the government telling researchers
what they should investigate is practically non-existent,
he says,for,in the words of Benjamin G. Willis, Director of
the Institute of Cooperative Research, all research done is
"what we want to do;in fact, the University can categorically state that it doesn't take on anything that we don't
want to do."
Another danger occurring in such a large trust on
government finances is that of "a cutback of federal
funds, which, on occassion, is somewhat material,"
according to Mr. Willis. Research grants lack continuity
due to the effects of budget cuts in Washington. Most
American universities are experiencing such cutbacks at

the present moment.
"Large Part"
Dr. Partridge asserted that the support of the government was "obviously a very large part of the budget and
it determines to a large extent the size of the university."
He went on to say, "if we decided to cut back federal
funds we would have an entirely different character of
institution . . . Our faculty turnover would be immense, because different people would want to be here."
The total government revenues sent to Hopkins are
subdivided, [ with respect to the contributing agency]
as follows: Department of Defense — $3,490,163;
Public Health Service — $20,317,182; other parts of
Health, Education and Welfare — $5,945,764; National
Science Foundation — $2,528,251; Atomic Energy
Commission — $984,707; other, such as Department of
Argiculture and Commerce, — $1,631,673; city, county/
and state governments — $516,809. And, of course,
there is the APL contract.

This organization has been the
result of several months work on

Council, Blue Key Society members, and personnel from the
Admissions Office of the University.
The purpose of the U.A.C. will
be to attract "prime candidates"
to Hopkins. One of the principal
tasks facing them is dispelling the
JHU image as a pre-med factory
and presenting a fuller picture of
the school.
Special attention is to be given
to attracting students from various
economic and social backgrounds,
such as Baltimore's Inner City.

assistant chairman of the UAC,
"The University presently overlooks or ignores black identity."
It is felt that on this "lily white"
campus the only way a black student can maintain his identity is
to withdraw from the academic
community.
The answer to this problem,
could be the inclusion of more
black students on the Hopkins
scene. However, of sixty black applicants, forty-five were accepted
last year, seventeen said that they
would come, and thirteen actually
did come. The UAC hopes to be
instrumental in enticing these students to come to Homewood.
The proposed plan called for
the creation of an Executive Committee who, in turn, elect Admissions Aides. Bearing the official
status as Admissions personnel,
these Aides will be able to work
through secondary school channels.
Although all students in the
Council will be entitled to interview the prime candidates, only
the Aides shall be able to talk with
guidance and other secondary
school personnel.
In the original draft, membership was open to all sophomores
and upperclassmen. Blue Key Society members were automatically
included. It was this aspect of the
proposal which sparked debate on
the measure.
It was first argued that Blue
Key members should not be entitled to privileged status as automatic members, but should be
compelled to apply to the Council
like all other students. It was
pointed out that the Blue Key represents an already select group of
students, a base from which the
UAC could draw during its formulative stages.
Matters were further complicated when opponents of the proposal asked why the creation of a
new agency was necessary to perform the functions which could be
accomplished by an expanded Blue
Key Society.
Russ Passarella, President of
the SC and one of the originators
of the UAC, retorted that the Blue
Key was essentially an on-campus
organization. "The advantage of
this is that it's done on a local
level." (Continued on Page 2)

Where heave
the heroes gone?

A young woman cries out her agony to
The Brooklyn sky
As good citizens dim their lights
So they may watch unseen
The late show in the streets.
A pregnant mother is harassed by hoodlums
While spectators stand mutely by.
And the young men?
The young men stand aside
Too smart to get involved.
In the current lingo they "keep their cool".
Well, listen here
No great civilizations have been built
By men who kept their cool ...
No frontiers conquered
No revolutions waged
No brave new societies forged
By men who kept their cool.
All of mankind's shining achievements
Have been propelled into being
By hot-blooded young men, fired by an idea.
When the heroes take to the sidelines
Civilizations decline and disappear.
Right now this country needs heroes
To stick out their necks
For better schools
Better housing
Better jobs
Better government.
It's up to you to take it on.
You are our life insurance.

Phoenix

A national poll of university
administrators, professors and
students has disclosed overwhelming agreement that students will
and should "serve as voting members on most important academic
committees on the typical campus
:
"
The report, issued by the
American Council on Education,
stated further that, "It may
surprise some students to know
that two out of three
administrators. . . believe this
development is desirable and
essential:'
The movement towards greater
participation in the administration
of the university has already shown
considerable progress in
universities and colleges today.
Morgan State
Morgan State College, for
example,has been allowing student
representation on administive
committees. Over 100 students are
presently involved in the 15
student body -orientated
organizations--in seven,they hold a
majority of the votes.
The two most important
committees at Morgan are the
Council on Student Conduct and
the Educational Policies
Committee.
The Council on Student
Conduct, for example, has six
student and six faculty
representatives, thus allowing for
equal representation of both
administration and undergraduate
viewpoints.
The Educational Policies
Committee, on the other hand, is
composed of seven' faculty
members and three student
representatives. It is this
committee which determines most
of the educational requirements
and general University policies
concerning what is taught at
Morgan.
Columbia
Columbia College has, since the
revolt of last May,granted students
some influence on university
committees. Last week, Dr.
Andrew Cordier, one time
diplomat, and acting-President of
Columbia, approved the admission
of students to the College's
Committee on Policy,Program and
Budget. Some faculty at Columbia
have hinted that once the

The University of Maryland,on
the other hand,appears to be going
in the opposite direction. Dr.
Wilson H. Elkins, President of
Maryland, said that the school has
named a variety of students to
advisory committees in recent
years and always welcomes student
opinion, providing it comes
"through channels." He stressed
that there are administrators
assigned to handle various areas of
compus life and students should go
to them to solve problems.
Dr. Elkins based hisjudgements
on his belief that students simply
don't want to administer.
Representation
Elkins added further that
"we're not an agency of reform. We
teach about politics but we don't

go about from door to door."
The national poll undertaken by
the American Council on
Education further indicated that
four out of five persons questioned
believe "the gradual substitution of
responsibility for self-regulation
instead of in loco parentis as a basis
for codes of non-academic student
conduct seems highly probable."
Discipline
Such a movement has also been
noted on some campuses. For
example, both Columbia and
Morgan State have either a Student
Court or a joint faculty-student
Committee on Disciplinary Affairs.

InFormation Please
It is no secret that there has been considerable conflict, over the
years, between university administrators and the organizations which
operate under the aegis of Dr. Chester Wickwire and Levering Hall.
Elements of this were present in last week's examination of
RESPONSE.
In the confusion over RESPONSE's role on campus, one heard new
versions of the ever-present rumors circulating among those connected
with Levering Hall: that Dr. Wickwire would be asked to leave or that
administration officials wanted veto power over programs emanating
from Levering.
There is no evidence to support such rumors. However, since the
organizations centered in Levering Hall are the most dynamic and
progressive on campus, on conflict concerning them is of interest to
the Hopkins community.
If the Hopkins community is to be concerned, it must be informed.
While investigating the many rumors which were floating around last
around last week, we noticed some discomforting indications that the
right to be informed was in danger.
Certain officials in Levering Hall organizations did their best to ensure that no News-Letter story would appear concerning RESPONSE,
much less any other problems which Levering faced.
Moreover, obtaining information from the University on any of its
bureaucratic infighting is like trying to get Spiro Agnew to expound on
the metaphysical implications of Finnegan's wake.
We hope that this situation will serve as a case in point when others
like it arise. In matters concerning the community, the administration
and organizations like those in Levering Hall must realize that they do
not possess inviolable fiefdoms idwhich the students and other concerned parties are relegated to the status of helpless spectators.

The great American migration
to the suburbs, the
massive scale
of American life in those suburbs
and the tremendous growth of
co
mmunications across the nation
have ushered a new era of American politics, according to Tom
Wicker, chief of the Washington
News Bureau of the N.Y. Times.
• In support of his claim, Mr.
Wicker cited the strange events
of the 1968 political season, as he
addressed an audience of about
350 people at
Shriver Hall this
Past Monday afternoon. He laid
Particular emphasis on the conduct of the
Democratic Party in
Chicago this past August.
At Chicago, The Democrats
chose Humphrey because he represented all the beliefs and policies
that have raised the party to power
and glory
during 28 of the last 36
Years. In this way, the Democrats
showed that they have become the
Party of the status quo with "definite establishment features."
'The role of a party is to win
a majority of the American voters," said Wicker,"but the Democjats ignored this role at Chicago."
Instead they nominated a man
'ho had the support of only a decidedL
minority of the nation.'
il_ins minority was the regulars of
T
we Democratic Party.
Other Sources
The decision of the DemocraPic Party ignored the growth of
Participation
politics," as Wicker
alls the American political style.
Tally voters no longer feel that
uteY need organization leaders to
tell them for whom they should
vote. Modern communications
have reduced the
need for old-time
°rganization leadership, and voters
now use
and opinion
Polls as thetelevision
bases on which they
nlake their decisions.
Wicker also pointed to earlier
,
uevelopments in this year's presidential campaign to illustrate his
Point. He claimed that Romney
had to drop
out of the race before
the first
test because he
had such primary
low ratings in the polls.
T. his, in
inability turn, was the result of his
to handle television in a
reliable way.

Drawing his conclusion from
these examples, Wicker said that
"the nature of our politics is
changing and 'participation politics' will be the mark of the coming political era."
Future Trends
As a footnote, he mentioned
several specific results of the rise
of"participation politics." He said
that there will be a greater emphasis on state primaries although
national conventions will remain
because of the need to build national coalitions. The electoral college will eventually be abolished
especially if Wallace does well this
year.
Good and Bad
systems may result
new
These
in more fairness because they will
promote the will of the majority.
At the same time, dangers will
arise because there will be fewer
safeguards against majority errors.
"We should not beat change on
the head with a stick," Wicker
warned, "but we should realize
that we will always have serious
problems."

The National Institute of
General Medical Sciences, National Institutes of Health, has
awarded research fellowships to
seven graduate and postdoctoral
members of the Biomedical
Engineering, Biology, and Chemistry departments of Hopkins.
The research fellowship program enables individuals of
competence and potential to
advance in , their scientific
fields.
Recipients of the awards are:
Dr. Richard F. Olivo, Biomedical Engineering (Neural Coding
in Auditory Cortex of Squirre
Monkeys"); Frank S. Werblin,
Biomedical Engineering ("Intracellular Recording Throughout
Vertebrate Retina"); Dr. Joseph
J. Feretti, Biology Department
("Genetics Biochemical Studies
on Salmonella typhimurium");
John B. Hays, Biology Department ("Biomedical Study of
Bacterial Sugar Transport");
Donald J. Roufa, Biology Department ("Graduate Studies in
Cell and Developmental Biology"); Gerald J. Handschuh,
Chemistry Department (Desazaporphyrin, a Porphyrin Analogue"); and Vernon V' Walatka,
Chemistry Department ("Electric Oxygen Relationships in
Hemoglobin.")
They are among the 2300
fellows supported in their research by the Institute.

Located off campus and involving no students or faculty, the
Ballistic Analysis Laboratory is a
totally classified complex. It engages in research for the U.S. Army
through methods of applied mathematics on penetrability of materials and aerial systems, under an
annual budget of about $600,000
The University's connection with
the program is being terminated
since, according to Dean Allyn
Kimball, "the lab has no connection with anything any member of
this faculty is interested in."
At the University's School of
Advanced International Studies in
Washington,under study is a classified project for the Arms Control
and Disarmament Agency on methods of dealing with violations of
arms control agreements.
Barton Laboratory conducts
studies of a classified nature on
electromagnetic techniques and
high resolution radar for the U.S.
Air Force at an annual expenditure
of about $800,000. It involves
research by some faculty and students, primarily from the department of electrical engineering.

About 75% of the work generated
in Barton Laboratory is published
in the open literature; the rest is
classified.
The heads of the departments
of Chemistry,Physics, and Biology
all indicate that their departments
do no military nor classified research. Dr. Owens, in stating his
own position, might speak for all
three: "It's not only a matter of
university policy, but there is also
a question of morality involved."

Hopkins Reliance on Government Grows
By JACK HOLLIS
According to Dr. Bruce J. Partridge, Vice-President
for Administration, 53% of the funds for the school's
Operating budget in the vear oA-7.
107g_irsice-1-915995.9.)111 governmental sources, an increase ot
Although this situation is what was termed by Dr.
Partridge as a "heavy reliance" on federal funds, Hopkins
..1.. dependence on government money has almost
always been to its own advantage. In fact, the University
is in a better position than many other institutions.
Hazards
In the period 1967-68 the total amount of money
received from the government was $35,414,549, almost
all of it going for research of one form or another. The
figure was approximately $9 million in 1959, when the
total operating budget was about $21 million, an amount
that has since risen to its present level of almost $69
rnillion. The statistics do not include the Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) in Silver Spring, which has a
Navy contract of $52,765,000 which Hopkins just
administrates.

There are two potential hazards within this large
dependence on government grants and contracts. Ross
Jones, Vice-President for University Affairs, stated that
"the ultimate danger is that government through control
of money will dictate what to do, but this has not happened in the last 20-25 years.
"What We Want"
The possibility of the government telling researchers
what they should investigate is practically non-existent,
he says,for,in the words of Benjamin G. Willis, Director of
the Institute of Cooperative Research, all research done is
"what we want to do;in fact, the University can categorically state that it doesn't take on anything that we don't
want to do."
Another danger occurring in such a large trust on
government finances is that of "a cutback of federal
funds, which, on occassion, is somewhat material,"
according to Mr. Willis. Research grants lack continuity
due to the effects of budget cuts in Washington. Most
American universities are experiencing such cutbacks at

the present moment.
"Large Part"
Dr. Partridge asserted that the support of the government was "obviously a very large part of the budget and
it determines to a large extent the size of the university."
He went on to say, "if we decided to cut back federal
funds we would have an entirely different character of
institution . . . Our faculty turnover would be immense, because different people would want to be here."
The total government revenues sent to Hopkins are
subdivided, [ with respect to the contributing agency]
as follows: Department of Defense — $3,490,163;
Public Health Service — $20,317,182; other parts of
Health, Education and Welfare — $5,945,764; National
Science Foundation — $2,528,251; Atomic Energy
Commission — $984,707; other, such as Department of
Argiculture and Commerce, — $1,631,673; city, county/
and state governments — $516,809. And, of course,
there is the APL contract.

considerable progress in

Morgan State
Morgan State College, for

committees. Over 100 students are

student and six faculty
representatives, thus allowing for
equal representation of both
administration and undergraduate
viewpoints.

of the educational requirements
and general University policies

InFormation Please
It is no secret that there has been considerable conflict, over the
years, between university administrators and the organizations which
operate under the aegis of Dr. Chester Wickwire and Levering Hall.
Elements of this were present in last week's examination of
RESPONSE.
In the confusion over RESPONSE's role on campus, one heard new
versions of the ever-present rumors circulating among those connected
with Levering Hall: that Dr. Wickwire would be asked to leave or that
administration officials wanted veto power over programs emanating
from Levering.
There is no evidence to support such rumors. However, since the
organizations centered in Levering Hall are the most dynamic and
progressive on campus, on conflict concerning them is of interest to
the Hopkins community.
If the Hopkins community is to be concerned, it must be informed.
While investigating the many rumors which were floating around last
around last week, we noticed some discomforting indications that the
right to be informed was in danger.
Certain officials in Levering Hall organizations did their best to ensure that no News-Letter story would appear concerning RESPONSE,
much less any other problems which Levering faced.
Moreover, obtaining information from the University on any of its
bureaucratic infighting is like trying to get Spiro Agnew to expound on
the metaphysical implications of Finnegan's wake.
We hope that this situation will serve as a case in point when others
like it arise. In matters concerning the community, the administration
and organizations like those in Levering Hall must realize that they do
not possess inviolable fiefdoms idwhich the students and other concerned parties are relegated to the status of helpless spectators.

The great American migration
to the suburbs, the
massive scale
of American life in those suburbs
and the tremendous growth of
co
mmunications across the nation
have ushered a new era of American politics, according to Tom
Wicker, chief of the Washington
News Bureau of the N.Y. Times.
• In support of his claim, Mr.
Wicker cited the strange events
of the 1968 political season, as he
addressed an audience of about
350 people at
Shriver Hall this
Past Monday afternoon. He laid
Particular emphasis on the conduct of the
Democratic Party in
Chicago this past August.
At Chicago, The Democrats
chose Humphrey because he represented all the beliefs and policies
that have raised the party to power
and glory
during 28 of the last 36
Years. In this way, the Democrats
showed that they have become the
Party of the status quo with "definite establishment features."
'The role of a party is to win
a majority of the American voters," said Wicker,"but the Democjats ignored this role at Chicago."
Instead they nominated a man
'ho had the support of only a decidedL
minority of the nation.'
il_ins minority was the regulars of
T
we Democratic Party.
Other Sources
The decision of the DemocraPic Party ignored the growth of
Participation
politics," as Wicker
alls the American political style.
Tally voters no longer feel that
uteY need organization leaders to
tell them for whom they should
vote. Modern communications
have reduced the
need for old-time
°rganization leadership, and voters
now use
and opinion
Polls as thetelevision
bases on which they
nlake their decisions.
Wicker also pointed to earlier
,
uevelopments in this year's presidential campaign to illustrate his
Point. He claimed that Romney
had to drop
out of the race before
the first
test because he
had such primary
low ratings in the polls.
T. his, in
inability turn, was the result of his
to handle television in a
reliable way.

Drawing his conclusion from
these examples, Wicker said that
"the nature of our politics is
changing and 'participation politics' will be the mark of the coming political era."
Future Trends
As a footnote, he mentioned
several specific results of the rise
of"participation politics." He said
that there will be a greater emphasis on state primaries although
national conventions will remain
because of the need to build national coalitions. The electoral college will eventually be abolished
especially if Wallace does well this
year.
Good and Bad
systems may result
new
These
in more fairness because they will
promote the will of the majority.
At the same time, dangers will
arise because there will be fewer
safeguards against majority errors.
"We should not beat change on
the head with a stick," Wicker
warned, "but we should realize
that we will always have serious
problems."

N.I.H. Awards Four JHU Branches
GrantstoProfs Do Secret Research
The National Institute of
General Medical Sciences, National Institutes of Health, has
awarded research fellowships to
seven graduate and postdoctoral
members of the Biomedical
Engineering, Biology, and Chemistry departments of Hopkins.
The research fellowship program enables individuals of
competence and potential to
advance in , their scientific
fields.
Recipients of the awards are:
Dr. Richard F. Olivo, Biomedical Engineering (Neural Coding
in Auditory Cortex of Squirre
Monkeys"); Frank S. Werblin,
Biomedical Engineering ("Intracellular Recording Throughout
Vertebrate Retina"); Dr. Joseph
J. Feretti, Biology Department
("Genetics Biochemical Studies
on Salmonella typhimurium");
John B. Hays, Biology Department ("Biomedical Study of
Bacterial Sugar Transport");
Donald J. Roufa, Biology Department ("Graduate Studies in
Cell and Developmental Biology"); Gerald J. Handschuh,
Chemistry Department (Desazaporphyrin, a Porphyrin Analogue"); and Vernon V' Walatka,
Chemistry Department ("Electric Oxygen Relationships in
Hemoglobin.")
They are among the 2300
fellows supported in their research by the Institute.

marine), space systems development, and supporting research and
exploratory development.
Located off campus and involving no students or faculty, the
Ballistic Analysis Laboratory is a
totally classified complex. It engages in research for the U.S. Army
through methods of applied mathematics on penetrability of materials and aerial systems, under an
annual budget of about $600,000
The University's connection with
the program is being terminated
since, according to Dean Allyn
Kimball, "the lab has no connection with anything any member of
this faculty is interested in."
At the University's School of
Advanced International Studies in
Washington,under study is a classified project for the Arms Control
and Disarmament Agency on methods of dealing with violations of
arms control agreements.
Barton Laboratory conducts
studies of a classified nature on
electromagnetic techniques and
high resolution radar for the U.S.
Air Force at an annual expenditure
of about $800,000. It involves
research by some faculty and students, primarily from the department of electrical engineering.

About 75% of the work generated
in Barton Laboratory is published
in the open literature; the rest is
classified.
The heads of the departments
of Chemistry,Physics, and Biology
all indicate that their departments
do no military nor classified research. Dr. Owens, in stating his
own position, might speak for all
three: "It's not only a matter of
university policy, but there is also
a question of morality involved."

The Orientation Committee is
sponsoring a 5 week long "Symposium on Aggression." Besides examing a topic of immediate interest, the series is intended to encourage dialogue among all members of the University community.
Dr. Charles Southwick will initiate the symposium with a talk
on "Aggression: Its Biological Bases in Animals and Humans." Dr.
Southwick is professor of pathobiology at the School of Public
Health and Hygiene and has long
been involved with studies of aggression in monkeys and other primates. He will speak this Sunday,
October 13th, at 8 p.m. in the
Great Hall of Levering.

Prepares For Opener
By MIKE SHORE
With a schedule expanded to
four games, Coach Bob Scott's
Baby Jay football team appears set
for the season's first clash against
the Franklin & Marshall Frosh on
the 25th of October.
Scotty must really be "sockin'
it to the freshmen since there are
only 35 players remaining from
the original 52 that tried out.
Scott's assistant is former Hopkins
end and current grad student Mike
Shaw.
Following F&M the froth visit
the Susquehanna J.V. on November 4 and return to Homewood for
battles with Penn Military and
Towson State on the 8th and 15th
of November. The traditionally
strong Freshman squad is hoping
to best last year's 2 and 1 showing.

slots and can count on some more

In addition to these front liners
there is excellent depth throughout the backfields.
The team's main weakness lies

these men are described by Coach
Scott as being high quality football

and potential, an injury to any of
these key players could leave a
gaping hole in either the offense
or the defense, or both.
